Correlation between BTC/ETH remains high but I bet this continues to deteriorate as their different use cases cement themselves. We see shades of that already https://t.co/wqmx7uNbQ8
On bear markets--> As expected for price action but notably builders keep building and downturns seem to be getting less severe and less protracted https://t.co/LnQ5mKqUUK

On Inflation--> While BTC and ETH havenâ€™t experienced a high correlation to inflationary pressures in the past, both tokens have popped the minute strong CPI numbers have been released the last few months. They also have tracked inflation expectations very closely https://t.co/HVf4qfjqcY
On Interest Rate Changes--> No surprises during rising or falling IR environments, they perform as expected but notably BTC/ETH are still inversely correlated to real yields https://t.co/qSGVrHnS4X

What about BTC? Strangely enough itâ€™s been tracking closer and closer to the large cap value index over time. The top names in the Russell 1000 value index are Berkshire Hathaway, J&J, JP Morgan, United Healthcare, P&G, Bank of America, and Exxon. https://t.co/t2nli7otMx

As cash flow has increased for ETH the last two years, correlation to the S&P and NASDAQ has increased. As most are aware the top 4 names in both are tech giants $aapl $msft $amzn $goog https://t.co/QA66fpWDKC

To the riskiest growth stocks BTC averages about a 35% correlation over the last four years while ETH averages about a 30% correlation over the same time period. Notably, Ethereum has been exhibiting a much lower correlation to low/no revenue technology stocks more recently. https://t.co/iB0WyTT8lZ

BTC and ETH are less risky than you think

RT @coinstackcrypto: Coinbase expects ETH staking yields to rise to 9 - 12% APR after the merge goes live in June this year.

Via: @CryptoGâ€¦

8/8 Along with directly sanctioning banks and the bank accounts of the Russian elite the US could financially cripple Russia and either escalate or end this thing fairly quickly. In the meantime Oil likely up, Ruble down, Dollar up, markets/crypto down

7/8  #crypto may come into play too. Unfortunately. Russia could use it to evade sanctions painting our industry again in the wrong light, BUT it remains to be seen if this could really be done at any scale.

6/8 80% of Russian transactions are done over SWIFT. Cutting them off from SWIFT would cripple their commerce for a period. The Europeans would feel some level of pain too as they rely on Russia for oil / nat gas. This could be the mechanism to end this thing quickly.

5/8 So can Russia get around a SWIFT sanction? Possibly. Russia has a very small but largely unused back up system (<20% transactions). There are NO alternatives to SWIFT for doing financial transactions internationally in any scale.

4/8 The US has threatened to sanction the platform itself if the US doesn't get its demands, such as when the US wanted to disconnect Iran from SWIFT in 2018 and other SWIFT members disagreed. The US won this battle. Again the US essentially indirectly controls SWIFT

3/8 SWIFT is an international agency overseen by the FED, BOE, ECB,BOJ and other major banks. The US doesn't control SWIFT but as the world's reserve currency almost all payments are dominated in dollars so the US essentially makes the rules for SWIFT.
2/8 SWIFT helps facilitate messages, which include payments/trades/exchanges, btw banks worldwide. They do ~42 million a day and serve as the backbone of the global payments network.

The US could cripple Russia with one move.

The harshest move the US could make today is banning #Russia from the #SWIFT international payments system
